questions.text: Which of the following best describes the difference between temporal summation and spatial summation in neurons?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no difference between Temporal summation and Spatial summation.

options.label: B
options.text: Temporal summation requires signals to occur close in time, spatial summation requires simultaneous signals at different synapses.

options.label: C
options.text: Temporal summation is not limited by the refractory period, spatial summation is.

options.label: D
options.text: Temporal summation combines signals from different synapses, spatial summation combines signals from the same synapse.

questions.correct_answer: B. Temporal summation requires signals to occur close in time, spatial summation requires simultaneous signals at different synapses.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Temporal Summation

Spatial Summation

Definition
(Option B)

Multiple subthreshold excitatory signals at the same synapse occurring close in time.

 

Excitatory signals arriving at different synapses simultaneously or within a short timeframe.

 

Threshold for Excitation
(Option D)

Summation of signals to reach the threshold potential for triggering an action potential.

Combined effect of excitatory signals at multiple synapses to reach the threshold.

Signal Source
(Option A)

Same synapse

Different synapses

Current Flow

Local depolarizing current spreads from the same synapse.

Local depolarizing currents from different synapses overlap.

Role in Action Potentials

Can trigger an action potential if signals are close enough in time to summate and reach threshold.

Can trigger an action potential if multiple signals from different locations summate to reach threshold.

Impact of Refractory Period
(Option C)

Limited by the refractory period; if signals are too far apart, they won't summate.

Not directly limited by the refractory period; depends on spatial proximity of signals.

Examples

Neurons receiving frequent, rapid signals at a single synapse.

Neurons receiving simultaneous input from multiple presynaptic neurons.

questions.text: Feedback control in voltage-gated ion channels in the membrane of neuron during action potential has been shown here. The phenomenon shown at point A is:
Neurologists decide to assess the excitability of different tissues by plotting the strength-duration relationship parameters on a graph. Which of the following tissues show the highest excitability?

A 35-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of tingling and numbness in her hands and feet. On examination, the neurologist decides to conduct nerve conduction studies to assess the function of her peripheral nerves. The results show a compound action potential (CAP) with multiple peaks and a biphasic waveform. What does the presence of multiple peaks indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: Summation of action potentials from a single nerve fiber

options.label: B
options.text: Different conduction velocities of various nerve fibers

questions.correct_answer: B. Different conduction velocities of various nerve fibers
questions.explanation:
Action Potential - Monophasic/ Biphasic/ Compound

Monophasic Action Potential:

Single directional deflection, recorded from a single fiber or small group.

Recording: One electrode inside the cell, the other outside.

Characteristics:

  • Single Peak: Indicates action potential of a single fiber or small group.
  • Amplitude: Does not significantly increase with stimulation strength
  • Follows All-or-nothing Principle. It states that once an action potential is initiated in a nerve fiber, it will travel the entire length of the fiber if the conditions are suitable, or it will not travel at all if the conditions are not right.

Biphasic Action Potential:

Two-phase action potential with positive and negative deflections.

Recording: Two electrodes of opposite polarity detect the wave of depolarization.

Characteristics:

  • Waveform: Upward deflection followed by a downward deflection.
  • Relation to CAP: Component of CAP, reflecting the activity of multiple fibers.

Compound Action Potential (CAP):

Summation of action potentials from different nerve fibers (Aα, Aβ, B, C) in a mixed nerve.

Recording: Electrodes placed on the surface of the mixed nerve.

Characteristics:

  • Multiple Peaks: Correspond to different conduction velocities; Aα fibers first.
  • Amplitude: Increases with stronger stimulation.
  • Waveform: Biphasic, showing positive and negative deflections.
  • Does not follow the All-or-nothing Principle.

questions.text: Which of the following would decrease the conduction velocity of an action potential along an axon?

options.label: A
options.text: Increasing the diameter of the axon.

options.label: B
options.text: Decreasing the capacitance of the membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the myelination of the axon.

questions.explanation:
Conduction velocity of the Action potential.

Factors Influencing
  • Myelination: Increases conduction velocity, enabling saltatory conduction. (Option D)
  • Axon Diameter: Larger diameter axons exhibit faster conduction velocities. (Option A)
  • Temperature: Higher temperatures increase ion channel opening and closing speeds affecting conduction velocity.

 

Classification of Nerve Fibers
  • Larger, myelinated fibers (like Aα fibers) - Faster conduction velocity.
  • Smaller, unmyelinated fibers (like C fibers) - Slower conduction velocity.

Clinical Significance

 

  • A decrease in chronaxie after nerve repair suggests increased excitability and potential regeneration.

Stimulus Strength

  • A stronger stimulus doesn't increase the speed of an action potential in a single nerve fiber, it might activate a greater number of fibers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the conduction of action potentials is TRUE?

options.label: A
options.text: Speed of action potential conduction is inversely proportional to the degree of myelination of the axon.

options.label: B
options.text: Saltatory conduction occurs in both myelinated and unmyelinated axons.

options.label: C
options.text: The action potential jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons.

options.label: D
options.text: The myelin sheath increases the flow of ions across the axonal membrane.

questions.correct_answer: C. The action potential jumps from one node of Ranvier to the next in myelinated axons.
questions.explanation:
Conduction of action potential

Feature

Unmyelinated

Myelinated

Conduction Speed

Slower (0.25 m/s)

Faster (up to 100 m/s)

Mechanism

Action potential flows continuously along the axon membrane. (Option B)

Action potential "jumps" between nodes of Ranvier-saltatory conduction.

Myelin Sheath

Absent

Present, decreases flow of ions, preventing ion leakage across the membrane. (Option D)

Nodes of Ranvier

Absent

Present, rapid action potential regeneration.

Energy Efficiency

Less energy efficient.

More energy efficient.

Fiber Diameter

Smaller

Larger

questions.text: What impact does hyperkalemia have on a neuron's resting membrane potential (RMP)?

options.label: A
options.text: It causes depolarization, making the neuron more excitable.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes hyperpolarization, making the neuron less excitable.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the RMP.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases the activity of the Na+/K+ -ATPase pump.

questions.correct_answer: A. It causes depolarization, making the neuron more excitable.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Hyperkalemia

Hypokalemia

RMP

Depolarized (Decreased RMP)

(Option C)

Hyperpolarized (Increased RMP)

(Option B)

Explanation
  • Increased extracellular potassium reduces the gradient for potassium to exit the cell, causing depolarization.
  • The resting membrane potential becomes less negative than the typical -70 mV.
  • In hypokalemia, cells lose more potassium ions due to leaky channels.
  • The loss of positive charge increases the negative charge within the cell, causing hyperpolarization.

Effect on Neuron Excitability
  • Increased excitability can lead to spontaneous firing and even cell death.
  • Persistent depolarization inactivates voltage-gated sodium channels, preventing action potential generation.
  • Decreased excitability occurs as the membrane potential is further from the threshold for action potential.
  • Hypokalemia also inhibits the Na-K-ATPase pump.

questions.text: During an action potential, the voltage-gated sodium channel transitions through different states. Which of the following sequences accurately reflects the order of these states during a single action potential cycle starting from RMP?
questions.explanation:
Stage

M Gate

H Gate

Description

Closed

 

Closed

Open

This is the resting state of the voltage-gated sodium channel, where the activation gate (M gate) is closed, preventing sodium ions from entering the cell.

Open

 

Open

Open
  • When the membrane potential becomes less negative, the activation gate opens rapidly.
  • This allows a large influx of sodium ions into the cell, leading to depolarization.

Inactive

 

 

Open

Closed
  • If the membrane potential remains depolarized for a prolonged period, the inactivation gate will close.
  • The closed inactivation gate prevents sodium ions from entering.

questions.text: Which statements accurately describe the refractory period on a neuron's signaling properties?

options.label: A
options.text: Ensures action potentials move in one direction along an axon.

options.label: B
options.text: Restricts the length of an action potential, stopping overly long depolarizations.

options.label: C
options.text: Sets the intensity needed to start an action potential (threshold level).

options.label: D
options.text: Aids in the summation of local potentials, facilitating action potential generation.

questions.correct_answer: A. Ensures action potentials move in one direction along an axon.
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Absolute Refractory Period

Relative Refractory Period

Definition
  • The initial phase of the refractory period.
  • The period during which a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus.
  • Follows the absolute refractory period
  • The period during which a stronger than-normal stimulus can elicit a second action potential.

Duration

Sum of the total depolarization period and the first 1/3rd of the repolarization period of the action potential.

Last 2/3rd of the repolarization period of the action potential.

Excitability

No stimulus, no matter how strong.

Stronger than normal stimuli

Voltage-Gated Na+ Channels

Inactive or open state.

Transition from the inactive to the closed state.

Significance

Limits the maximum frequency of action potentials a neuron can fire.

Encoding of stimulus strength by modulating the frequency of action potentials.

questions.text: Based on the graph showing potassium ion permeability during an action potential, at which point does the permeability of potassium ions reach its peak?
The graph below depicts an action potential. Which of the following statements correctly describes the state of ion channels at the point marked "X" on the graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Na+ channels are closed; K+ channels are open.

options.label: B
options.text: Na+ channels are completely inactivated; K+ channels are open.

options.label: C
options.text: Na+ and K+ channels are open.

options.label: D
options.text: Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

questions.correct_answer: B. Na+ channels are completely inactivated; K+ channels are open.
questions.explanation:
Phase

Membrane Potential

Na+ Channels

K+ Channels

Resting State

Polarized (-70 mV)

Closed

Closed

Depolarization (Rising Phase)

Less negative, towards 0 mV.

Rapidly opening, then inactivating

Slowly opens.

Overshoot (Peak)

Briefly positive (+35 mV).

Inactivated

Open

Repolarization (Falling Phase)

Returning to negative

Inactivated

Open

After-hyperpolarization

More negative.

Closed

Slowly closing

Return to Resting State

(Option D)

Returning to -70 mV

Closed

Closed

questions.text: A 75-year-old bedridden patient presents with severe pressure ulcers over the sacral region and complaints of muscle weakness and numbness in the lower limb. On examination, there is evidence of compromised blood flow and significant tissue damage. Which layer of the peripheral nerve is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Endoneurium

(Option B)
  • The endoneurium is a layer of connective tissue covering each nerve fibre within its Schwann cell and basal lamina in a peripheral nerve.
  • Contains collagen, fibroblast,schwann cells, endothelial cells and macrophages.
  • Endoneurium holds adjoining nerve fibres together and facilitates their aggregation to form fasciculi.

Perineurium

(Option A)
  • A thick layer of connective tissue covering each fascicle is called Perineurium.
  • It comprises layers of flattened cells separated by layers of collagen fibres.
  • Controls diffusion of substances in and out of axons.

Epineurium

(Option C)
  • The fasciculi are held together by a fairly dense layer of connective tissue that surrounds the entire nerve and is called Epineurium.
  • Contribute to the tensile strength of the nerve.
  • Loss of this layer in bedridden patients can lead to pressure on nerve fibres and paralysis.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately compares local potentials and action potentials?

options.label: A
options.text: Local potentials are all-or-none; action potentials are graded and decremental.

options.label: B
options.text: Local potentials can summate and are decremental; action potentials are all-or-nothing and non-decremental.

options.label: C
options.text: Local potentials have constant amplitude; action potentials vary and diminish with distance.

options.label: D
options.text: Both local and action potentials propagate without diminishing and can summate.

questions.correct_answer: B. Local potentials can summate and are decremental; action potentials are all-or-nothing and non-decremental.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Local Potentials

Action Potentials

Amplitude
(Vs Option A&C)

Graded; varies with stimulus strength

All-or-nothing; amplitude remains constant once threshold is reached

Propagation
 

Decremental; diminishes with distance

Non-decremental; maintains magnitude over long distances

Summation

(Option B)

Can summate (spatial and temporal)

Cannot summate; separated by refractory periods

Function

Initiate action potentials by reaching threshold at the axon hillock

Transmit signals over long distances along nerve fibers

Ionic Basis

Involves ion movements, similar to action potentials, but often localized

Depolarization and repolarization driven by voltage-gated Na⁺ and K⁺ channels

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the changes in the resting membrane potential (RMP) of neuron during depolarization and hyperpolarization?

options.label: A
options.text: Depolarization: RMP more negative; Hyperpolarization: RMP more positive.

options.label: B
options.text: Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP more negative.

options.label: C
options.text: Depolarization: RMP more negative; Hyperpolarization: RMP -65 mV.

options.label: D
options.text: Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP less negative.

questions.correct_answer: B. Depolarization: RMP more positive; Hyperpolarization: RMP more negative.
questions.explanation:
Depolarization:
  • Sudden shift from negative to positive membrane potential.
  • Mechanism: Increased permeability to Na⁺ ions allows rapid influx of Na⁺, neutralizing the negative potential.
  • In large nerve fibers, Na⁺ influx can cause the membrane potential to briefly become positive (overshoot).
  • Excitatory Postsynaptic Potentials (EPSPs):
    • Depolarizing events that can trigger an action potential.
    • Excitatory neurotransmitters bind to receptors, opening ion channels and allowing positively charged ions to enter.
    • Action potential is triggered if depolarization reaches around -45 mV.

Repolarization:
  • Return of membrane potential to resting state (-65 mV) following depolarization.
  • Na⁺ channels close, reducing Na⁺ influx.
  • K+ channels open wider, allowing K⁺ ions to exit rapidly.
  • Restores negative membrane potential.

Hyperpolarization:
  • Membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting potential, below -65 mV.
  • Inhibitory Neurotransmitters: Open channels allowing negatively charged ions (e.g., Cl⁻) to enter or positively charged (e.g., K⁺) to exit.
  • Prolonged Potassium Channel Opening: Allows additional K⁺ outflow.
  • Effect: Moves potential closer to the potassium Nernst potential, making the neuron less likely to fire immediately.
  • Recovery: Gradual return to threshold potential for new action potential generation.
  • Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potentials (IPSPs):
    • Hyperpolarizing events that make it harder for the neuron to fire an action potential.

Process

Membrane Potential Change

Ion Movement/Channel Activity

Threshold Impact

Resting Potential

~ -65 mV

Higher K⁺ inside than outside

Neutral

Depolarization

More positive

Na⁺ influx (channels open)

Possible Action Potential

EPSP

More positive

Positive ions enter

Triggers Action Potential if threshold reached

Repolarization

Returns to -65 mV

from peak of depolarization

Na⁺ channels close, K⁺ channels open wider

Returns to resting state

Hyperpolarization

More negative than -65 mV

Cl⁻ enters or K⁺ exits (channels remain open)

Less likely to fire immediately

IPSP

More negative

Negative ions enter or K⁺ exits

Inhibits action potential

questions.text: Match the ion with its equilibrium potential in a normal mammalian cell. Ion Equilibrium Potential (mV) 1. Sodium A. -70 2. Chloride B. +63 3. Potassium C. +132 4. Calcium D. -90
questions.explanation:
Ion

Equilibrium Potential

Sodium

+63 mV

Chloride

-70 mV

Potassium

-90 mV

Calcium

+132 mV

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with symptoms of confusion and lethargy. Her blood test shows a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. The intracellular concentration of sodium ([Na⁺]ᵢ) is 12 mEq/L. what is the equilibrium potential for sodium (in mV)?
Which of the following is true regarding the leak channels?

options.label: A
options.text: Facilitate the rapid transmission of action potentials along the axon.

options.label: B
options.text: Responsible for generation of synaptic potentials at the postsynaptic membrane

options.label: C
options.text: Help in maintaining resting membrane potential by allowing passive movement of ions

options.label: D
options.text: Play a crucial role in the repolarization phase of the action potential

questions.correct_answer: C. Help in maintaining resting membrane potential by allowing passive movement of ions

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the phenomenon where the distribution of ion species across a semipermeable membrane is influenced by the presence of a non-permeable ion, resulting in an uneven distribution of permeable ions?
Which of the following is NOT true regarding resting membrane potential?

options.label: A
options.text: It is created by diffusion of K+ from outside to inside the cell at rest

options.label: B
options.text: The RMP of cardiac muscle is -90 mV

options.label: C
options.text: K+ is the major determinant of RMP

options.label: D
options.text: The major contributor of RMP is through passive diffusion of ions

questions.correct_answer: A. It is created by diffusion of K+ from outside to inside the cell at rest
questions.explanation:
Cell

RMP

Neuron

-70mV

Skeletal muscle

-95mV

Smooth muscle

-60mV

Cardiac muscle

-90mV (option B)

Astrocyte

-90mV

Erythrocyte

-12mV

Photoreceptor

-40mV (dark) to -70mV (light)

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the type, direction and mediators of axonal transport? 1 Anterograde Cell body to axon terminal Dynein 2 Anterograde Axon terminal to cell body Kinesin 3 Retrograde Axon terminal to cell body Dynein 4 Retrograde Cell body to axon terminal Kinesin
questions.explanation:
Type

Mediated by

Characteristics

Anterograde transport

Kinesin
  • It involves the transport of cellular material from soma to the axon terminal.
  • It is responsible for the transport of proteins, synaptic vesicles necessary for synaptic transmission.
  • Two types:
  • Fast axoplasmic transport at a rate of 400 mm/day, mediated by kinesin.
  • Slow axoplasmic transport at a rate of 0.5-2 mm/day, mediated by actin, neurofilaments and microtubules. Supplies material required for regeneration following nerve injury.

Retrograde transport

Dynein
  • It involves the transport from axon terminals to soma at a rate of about 200 mm/day.
  • It is important for transport of viruses, toxins, nerve growth factors and reuptake of synaptic neurotransmitters.

questions.text: Which type of neuron is primarily involved in the transmission of visual information from the retina to the brain?
questions.correct_answer: D. Both multipolar and bipolar neuron
questions.explanation:
Type

Characteristic

Unipolar neuron

(Option A)
  • Seen in invertebrates Have one process with several receptive and releasing terminals

Bipolar neurons (Option B)
  • Seen in retina and olfactory epithelium
  • Have two specialized processes
  • Dendrite carries information to the cell
  • Axon carries information from the cell

Pseudo-unipolar neurons
  • Seen in dorsal root ganglion.
  • The developing neuron has a single process that splits into two, both of which function as axons, one reaching up to the skin and the other to the spinal cord

Multipolar neurons

(Option C)
  • Most common
  • Seen in ganglion cell, hippocampal pyramidal cells, cerebellar Purkinje cells, motor neurons, etc
  • Have one axon and multiple dendrites

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness and fatigue. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies indicate that the issue lies in the transmission of nerve impulses to his muscles, while central nervous system imaging shows no abnormalities. Which part of the neuron is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
1. Dendritic zone (Receptor zone)
  • Receives information from other neurons and transmits impulses towards the cell body.
  • Integrates local potentials from synaptic connections.

2. Axon Hillock and Initial segment  (Action Potential Generation zone) 
  • Action potentials are generated here.
  • In motor neurons, it occurs at the axon hillock; in sensory neurons, at the initial node of Ranvier.
  • Summates local potentials from dendrites and generates action potentials if the threshold is reached.

3. Axon
(Transmission zone)
  • Long, slender process transmitting action potentials from the cell body to axon terminals.
  • Ensures rapid and efficient propagation of nerve impulses over long distances.

4. Axon Terminal (Discharge zone)
  • Contains synaptic vesicles with neurotransmitters.
  • When an action potential reaches the axon terminal, it triggers neurotransmitter release into the synaptic cleft for communication with other neurons or target cells.

questions.text: In which part of the neuron are neurofibrillary tangles primarily found, which are associated with neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's?
questions.explanation:
Axon

Cell Body (Soma)

Dendrites
  • Long tubular process extending from the cell body to transmit signals to target organs.
     
  • Originates from the axon hillock, a thickened area of the cell body.
     
  • The initial segment, just after the axon hillock, is where action potentials are generated.
     
  • Axon terminal: The terminal part of the axon loses myelin and branches into telodendria, which end in synaptic knobs (terminal buttons) containing neurotransmitters.
  • It is the center of the neuron containing the nucleus, which is the metabolic center and stores DNA.
     
  • Contains organelles like Nissl bodies (stacks of endoplasmic reticulum with ribosomes), mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, and lysosomes.
     
  • Capable of protein synthesis with numerous Nissl granules.
     
  • Lacks centrioles, limiting regenerative capacity.
     
  • Contains cytoskeletal proteins like neurofilaments, microtubules, and actin microfilaments (In Alzheimer’s, neurofilaments form neurofibrillary tangles).
  • These are numerous short extensions from the cell body that receive incoming signals and transmit them into the cell body.
     
  • Have dendritic spines to increase surface area for signal reception.
     
  • Contain Nissl granules for protein synthesis; involved in generating and conducting action potentials.
     
  • Typically, about 10,000 dendrites per neuron are in the CNS.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with brain tumor undergoes treatment with a novel chemotherapy drug targeting tumor cells. Despite the initial response, follow-up imaging shows minimal response and tumor progression. Which characteristic of the blood-brain barrier is responsible for this treatment challenge?

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of fenestrations in capillary walls

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of efflux transporters for drugs

questions.explanation:
Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB)

The BBB is the barrier between capillary endothelial cells in the brain and epithelial cells in the choroid plexus, limiting the exchange of substances into the brain.

Anatomical Basis

Formed by two special structures:

  1. Endothelial cells in brain capillaries are joined by tight junctions.
  2. Capillaries are surrounded by astrocyte foot processes.

Permeability

Easily Penetrated: Water, CO2, O2, lipid-soluble substances.

Not Penetrated: Proteins, polypeptides.

Circumventricular organs

The BBB is deficient in certain brain regions known as circumventricular organs, which are outside the BBB:

  1. Organum vasculosum of lamina terminalis (OVLT)
  2. Subfornical Organ
  3. Area postrema in medulla oblongata
  4. Posterior pituitary and median eminence(ventral part) of hypothalamus
  5. Pineal gland

Functions of BBB
  • Maintain constancy of Na+, K+, Ca++, H+ and Mg++ in brain fluids
  • Protect neurons from harmful toxins
  • Prevents escape of neurotransmitters from brain into circulation
  • Disruption of BBB helps in identifying the location and extent of lesions in the brain

Clinical importance
  1. Kernicterus: Hyperbilirubinemia damages the basal ganglia in infants due to an underdeveloped BBB.
  2. Brain Tumor: BBB is disrupted at the tumor site.
  3. Infection and Injury: BBB breakdown occurs in infected or injured regions.
